title: Ricky Stuart says American college football inspired Raiders Viking clap
text:
Canberra Raiders coach Ricky Stuart has credited an American college football game for spawning the team's iconic Viking clap.

Mr Stuart was in awe after watching the crowd erupt at a Los Angeles NFL game during 2015, deciding to adopt the ritual for the Raider's fanbase.

Canberra faces the Sydney Roosters in their first Grand Final in 25 years on Sunday with the hopes the roar of the Viking clap will lead them to victory.

Raider's marketing and commercial manager, Jason Mathie, who attended the college games with Mr Stuart took hundreds of notes on the crowd atmosphere.

'(Stuart) said, ''we've got to have something like that at our game every time we score a try'',' Mr Mathie told The Sydney Morning Herald.

'The whole cogs started to turn for us. I said we need to develop something that's iconic for the club.'

After witnessing the impact the clap had at the NFL games, the Raiders decided to try it out themselves.

Just last week more than 26,000 Raiders fans performed the Viking clap during the team's preliminary final against South Sydney Rabbitohs (pictured Raiders fans performing Viking clap)

After witnessing the impact the clap had at the NFL games, the Raiders coach Ricky Stuart (pictured) decided to take on the ritual

It became so popular that a horn was even built to signal the start of the clap, made by the father of the club's media manager, Wayne Pollack.

Just last week more than 26,000 Raiders fans performed the Viking clap during the team's preliminary final against South Sydney Rabbitohs.

Mr Mathie said the ritual had brought in a whole new demographic of fans to the games.

He said there was noticeably more women and kids who were now coming to the Raider's matches.

Canberra's co-captain, Jarrod Croker said there was no real build up to the clap and many of the team members weren't sure if it would succeed.

'When it came out I just got chills. I thought, 'how good is this?' It was unreal,' he said.

The two teams will face off at Sydney's ANZ stadium on Sunday night as more than 80,000 fans are expected to attend.
description: The Canberra Raiders will face the Sydney Roosters during their first Grand Final on Sunday night with thousands of fans expected to perform the iconic Viking clap.
authors: Eliza Mcphee For Daily Mail Australia
